title: 105_s2513
content:
The Oregon Public Land Transfer and Protection Act of 1998 includes provisions for land transfers involving Rogue River National Forest and other public land in Oregon, as well as protection of Oregon and California Railroad Grant land and conveyance to Deschutes County, Oregon. The Oregon Public Land Transfer and Protection Act of 1998 involves transferring approximately 2,058 acres of public domain land within Rogue River National Forest in Oregon to the jurisdiction of the Secretary of Agriculture for management in accordance with relevant laws. The Oregon Public Land Transfer and Protection Act of 1998 transfers 1,632 acres of land from Rogue River National Forest to unreserved public domain status under the jurisdiction of the Secretary of the Interior. The land will be administered according to laws applicable to unreserved public domain land. The Federal land within Rogue River National Forest, approximately 4,298 acres, is restored to revested Oregon and California Railroad grant land status. Administrative jurisdiction over this land is transferred from the Secretary of Agriculture to the Secretary of the Interior for management under specific laws applicable to revested railroad grant land. Approximately 960 acres of revested Oregon and California Railroad grant land within Rogue River National Forest is transferred to the Secretary of Agriculture for management in accordance with specific laws applicable to the National Forest System. Approximately 960 acres of Oregon and California Railroad grant land within Rogue River National Forest is transferred to the Secretary of Agriculture for management in accordance with specific laws. The boundaries of the forest are adjusted to include the transferred land and exclude private property interests. Revenue distribution from the transferred land follows the Act of August 28, 1937. The Act transfers 960 acres of Oregon and California Railroad grant land within Rogue River National Forest to the Secretary of Agriculture. The forest boundaries are adjusted to include the transferred land and exclude private property interests. Maps of the changes must be available for public inspection within 60 days. The Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture must update public land records and publish notices of administrative jurisdiction changes in the Federal Register. TITLE II--PROTECTION OF OREGON AND CALIFORNIA RAILROAD GRANT LAND

SEC. 201. DEFINITIONS. The title defines "O & C land" as Oregon and California Railroad grant land managed by the Secretary of the Interior, "CBWR land" as Coos Bay Wagon Road grant land also managed by the Secretary of the Interior, and "public domain land" as having the same meaning as "public lands." The term "public domain land" refers to public lands as defined in the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976, excluding O & C land and CBWR land. The term "geographic area" pertains to specific districts within the State of Oregon managed by the Bureau of Land Management. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. SEC. 202 of the Act ensures no net loss of O & C land, CBWR land, or public domain land in a specific geographic area during land sales, purchases, and exchanges. The number of acres available for timber harvesting must not decrease over 10-year periods. SEC. 203 clarifies that the Act does not apply to land exchanges authorized under a specific law if consistent with a memorandum of understanding. TITLE III--CONVEYANCE TO DESCHUTES COUNTY, OREGON

SEC. 301. CONVEYANCE TO DESCHUTES COUNTY, OREGON. The Secretary of the Interior is authorized to sell certain land to Deschutes County, Oregon for clean water protection and social service development purposes, including private residential compensation, acquisition for nonprofit and governmental entities, and providing community amenities at little to no cost. The Secretary of the Interior may sell approximately 544 acres of land in Deschutes County, Oregon to the County at fair market value. The land includes various government lots and portions, with the purpose of assisting in the implementation of the Deschutes County Regional Problem Solving Project. The Secretary of the Interior may sell approximately 544 acres of land in Deschutes County, Oregon to the County at fair market value. The land includes various government lots and portions, with the purpose of assisting in the implementation of the Deschutes County Regional Problem Solving Project. The Secretary shall convey the land only if it is suitable for sale through the land use planning process. The amount paid by the County for the conveyance of land will go into a special account. The land in Deschutes County, Oregon may be sold to the County at fair market value to assist in the Regional Problem Solving Project. The amount paid for the land will be deposited in a special account and may be used by the Secretary for purchasing environmentally sensitive land in Oregon. The Senate passed the legislation on October 9, 1998. Attest: GARY SISCO, Secretary.
